column1: {{c1::Purpose clauses}} function {{c2::adverbially}} whereas {{c1::jussive noun clauses}} function {{c2::as direct objects}}.
Volō, nōlō, and mālō sometimes introduce {{c1::jussive noun clauses}}, although they are also commonly followed by {{c1::infinitives}}, like {{c1::iubeō nearly always does}}.

The common irregular verb fīō, fierī {{c1::is not::is/is not}} deponent and means {{c1::to occur, to happen, to become}}, but also is used {{c1::in place of the passive of the present system of faciō}}, having additional meanings {{c1::with active voice yet passive meaning in the present system only: to be done, to be made}}.

The common irregular verb fīō, fierī shares {{c1::its perfect passive system}} with {{c1::faciō}}, conveying additional meanings {{c1::with passive voice and active meaning in the perfect system only: "to have/had/will have occured," "to have/had/will have happened," "to have/had/will have become"}}.
Fīō, fierī: stem vowel {{c1::ī}} is long in all places except {{fit, fierī, and the imperfect subjunctive}}.
Fīō, fierī: {{c1::present subjunctive and imperfect, future, and (most of) present indicative}} follow the pattern of {{c2::audiō}} with a stem of {{c2::fī-}}.
